### Why GitHub CI was failing (and what I changed)
Your root CI workflow (`.github/workflows/ci.yml`) was **not aligned with this repo‚Äôs actual tooling**, and the repo‚Äôs root `pnpm test` was brittle:

- **pnpm version mismatch**: CI was installing **pnpm v9**, but the repo is pinned to **pnpm 10.28.1** (`packageManager`), which can break installs/lockfile behavior.
- **core tests were failing when no tests exist**: `@rn-sane-charts/core` ran `vitest run` which exits **1** when there are no test files, causing `pnpm test` to fail in CI.

I pushed a fix that:
- Updates CI to use **pnpm 10.28.1** and `pnpm install --frozen-lockfile`
- Updates core tests to `vitest run --passWithNoTests`

So CI should now get past `pnpm install` + `pnpm test`.

### Steps to run the example app locally (SDK 55, dev build, physical device `DJR_16ProMax`)
Prereqs:
- iPhone is **connected**, **unlocked**, **trusted**, and **Developer Mode** is enabled.
- Xcode can see it (in Xcode Devices & Simulators).

From repo root:

1) Install workspace deps:

```bash
pnpm install
```

2) Build + install the dev client onto your phone (this repo already sets the device target):

```bash
pnpm --dir packages/examples run ios
```

That runs `expo run:ios -d "DJR_16ProMax"` and will prebuild `packages/examples/ios/` if needed.

- **If you hit signing issues**: open `packages/examples/ios/examples.xcworkspace` in Xcode, set your Team under Signing & Capabilities for the `examples` target, then rerun the command.

3) Start Metro in dev-client mode:

```bash
pnpm --dir packages/examples run start:dev-client
```

4) Launch the installed app on your phone and it should connect to Metro.

### Notes
- Your working tree currently shows local-only changes (`packages/core/dist/` and a `.specstory` file modification). Those shouldn‚Äôt affect CI unless you commit them; `packages/core/dist/` is just a local build artifact.

### What those errors usually mean
- **`CoreAudioTypes` / `UIUtilities` not found + `SwiftUICore` not allowed client + `sk_abort_no_print()`**: almost always a **stale / mismatched native build state** (old Pods / DerivedData / prebuild output) after dependency changes (especially Skia), so the final link step pulls the wrong bits and collapses.

### Fix (clean native state, then rebuild)
From repo root:

```bash
pnpm install
pnpm --dir packages/examples run ios:rebuild
```

That script nukes `packages/examples/ios` + `packages/examples/.expo` and then re-runs `expo run:ios` (fresh prebuild + fresh pods), which is the most reliable way to clear those linker failures.

If it *still* fails, also clear Xcode DerivedData for this app and retry:

```bash
rm -rf ~/Library/Developer/Xcode/DerivedData/examples-*
pnpm --dir packages/examples run ios:rebuild
```

### Repo change I made to reduce Skia-related link weirdness
- Set `packages/examples/app.json` iOS `deploymentTarget` to **16.0** (Skia‚Äôs bundled iOS simulator libs are built with a newer minimum; this avoids ‚Äúbuilt for newer iOS-simulator version‚Äù warnings turning into hard failures in some setups).
- Added `packages/examples/package.json` scripts: `ios:clean` and `ios:rebuild`.

[Paragraph \| React Native Skia](https://shopify.github.io/react-native-skia/docs/text/paragraph/)&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;# Creating Default Fonts in @shopify/react-native-skia&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;## System Fonts Without TTF Files&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;To create a default font without requiring a TTF file, use **system fonts** via &#96;Skia.FontMgr.System()&#96;.[1] You can match system fonts using &#96;matchFont()&#96; with a font style object:&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&#96;&#96;&#96;javascript&lt;br/&gt;import \{ Canvas, Text, matchFont, Fill, Skia \} from "@shopify/react-native-skia";&lt;br/&gt;import \{ Platform \} from "react-native";&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;const fontFamily = Platform.select(\{ ios: "Helvetica", default: "serif" \});&lt;br/&gt;const fontStyle = \{&lt;br/&gt;  fontFamily,&lt;br/&gt;  fontSize: 14,&lt;br/&gt;  fontStyle: "italic",&lt;br/&gt;  fontWeight: "bold",&lt;br/&gt;\};&lt;br/&gt;const font = matchFont(fontStyle);&lt;br/&gt;&#96;&#96;&#96;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;By default, &#96;matchFont()&#96; uses the system font manager, so no custom font manager is needed.[1]&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;## Available System Fonts&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;List available system fonts using &#96;listFontFamilies()&#96;:[1]&lt;br/&gt;- **Android**: "sans-serif", "arial", "helvetica", "tahoma", "verdana", etc.&lt;br/&gt;- **iOS**: "Helvetica", "American Typewriter", "Academy Engraved LET", etc.&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;## Alternative: Typeface Creation&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;For non-TTF font creation, you can use &#96;Skia.Typeface.MakeFreeTypeFaceFromData()&#96; with font data loaded via &#96;Skia.Data.fromBytes()&#96; or &#96;Skia.Data.fromURI()&#96;.[2] However, this approach still requires font data.&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;**Note:** The basic &#96;Text&#96; component requires explicit font loading.[4] For automatic font fallbacks, consider using the &#96;Paragraph&#96; API instead.[1] |

-  "markdown": "Expo SDK 55 Beta is now available - Expo Changelog\n[\nAll Posts\n](https://expo.dev/changelog)\n# Expo SDK 55 Beta is now available\nJan 22, 2026by\n![Alan Hughes](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/fbc6f8287ef11f9f25db8039fee4ea8445dd7fe2-460x460.jpg?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;w=26)\nAlan Hughes\n![Brent Vatne](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/6aa3e387c3c72e9774c61a8398bbc2f9c427270a-400x400.webp?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;w=26)\nBrent Vatne\n![SDK 55 Beta](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/b96827559d51405d7aeb65ed14aeb02d5009cc8a-2400x1350.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;w=1200)\n**The SDK 55 beta period begins today and will last approximately two weeks.**The beta is an opportunity for developers to test out the SDK and ensure that the new release does not introduce any regressions for their particular systems and app configurations. We will be continuously releasing fixes and improvements during the beta period ‚Äîsome of these may include breaking changes.\nSDK 55 beta includes React Native 0.83.1 and React 19.2.0. The full release notes for SDK 55 won&amp;amp;#x27;t be available until the stable release, but you can browse the changelogs in the[expo/expo repository](https://github.com/expo/expo)to learn more about the scope of the release and any breaking changes. We&amp;amp;#x27;ll merge all changelogs into the root[**CHANGELOG.md**](http://CHANGELOG.md)when the beta is complete.\nWe&amp;amp;#x27;re also[hosting office hours on Discord](https://chat.expo.dev/)for those of you interested in helping test the release!\n[## **Dropped support for the Legacy Architecture**\n](#dropped-support-for-the-legacy-architecture)\nAs explained in the SDK 54 release notes - ‚Äú[SDK 54 is the final release to include Legacy Architecture support](https://expo.dev/changelog/sdk-54#sdk-54-is-the-final-release-to-include-legacy-architecture-support)‚Äù. In other words, you will not be able to use the Legacy Architecture in SDK 55 projects and later. Accordingly, the&amp;#96;newArchEnabled&amp;#96;config option has been removed from**app.json**.[Learn more in the ‚ÄúReact Native‚Äôs New Architecture‚Äù guide](https://docs.expo.dev/guides/new-architecture/).\n[## **Revamped default project template**\n](#revamped-default-project-template)\n![Screenshots of the main screen of the new default template on all supported platforms](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/f1aecee787f1b04c356aa2e149465d3f8ea7470e-1811x1056.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;w=800)\nThe default template has been redesigned with a focus on native platform conventions and an improved project folder structure:\n* **Uses the Native Tabs API**for a platform-native tab experience on iOS and Android, with a responsive web-optimized layout for browsers.\n* **Refreshed design**for a better out-of-the-box experience.\n* **New /src folder structure**, so application code now lives in**/src/app**instead of**/app**, better separating your code from project configuration files.[## **Hermes v1 is now available for opt-in**\n](#hermes-v1-is-now-available-for-opt-in)\nHermes v1 includes represents a huge step forward for the engine, showing early signs of[meaningful performance improvements across various scenarios](https://blog.swmansion.com/welcoming-the-next-generation-of-hermes-67ab5679e184), and shipping better support for[modern JavaScript features](https://x.com/Baconbrix/status/2001337091779633176?s=20)(ES6 classes, const/let syntax, async/await). You can try it out in your app with the&amp;#96;useHermesV1&amp;#96;field in&amp;#96;expo-build-properties&amp;#96;. It‚Äôs important to note that using Hermes v1 in Expo SDK 55 / React Native 0.83 requires building React Native from source, which significantly increases native build times. This tradeoff might be worth it for your app, give it a try, find out, and let us know!\napp.json\nCopy\n&amp;#96;&amp;#96;&amp;#96;\n{\n&amp;amp;quot;expo&amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;quot;plugins&amp;amp;quot;:[\n[\n&amp;amp;quot;expo-build-properties&amp;amp;quot;,\n{\n&amp;amp;quot;buildReactNativeFromSource&amp;amp;quot;:true,\n&amp;amp;quot;useHermesV1&amp;amp;quot;:true\n}\n]\n]\n}\n}\n&amp;#96;&amp;#96;&amp;#96;\nYou will need to override the&amp;#96;hermes-compiler&amp;#96;version to use the Hermes V1 compiler. Depending on your package manager, this field may be named differently. With npm and bun, the field is named&amp;#96;overrides&amp;#96;. For example:\npackage.json\nCopy\n&amp;#96;&amp;#96;&amp;#96;\n{\n&amp;amp;quot;dependencies&amp;amp;quot;:{},\n&amp;amp;quot;overrides&amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;quot;hermes-compiler&amp;amp;quot;:&amp;amp;quot;250829098.0.4&amp;amp;quot;\n}\n}\n&amp;#96;&amp;#96;&amp;#96;\n****\n[## **Hermes bytecode diffing is now available**\n](#hermes-bytecode-diffing-is-now-available)\nThe Hermes bytecode diffing feature in&amp;#96;expo-updates&amp;#96;and[EAS Update](https://expo.dev/services#update)is an optimization that significantly reduces update download sizes for Hermes-compiled JavaScript bundles. Instead of downloading complete Hermes bytecode files for each update, the&amp;#96;expo-updates&amp;#96;client can request and apply binary patches (diffs) to the previously installed bytecode files.\nThis means**your updates will be downloaded more quickly by end-users**, and that**each update will use less bandwidth**. That all translates to faster update adoption rates and more updates available within the bandwidth of your EAS plan.**It‚Äôs estimated that diffs will result in an approximately 75% reduction in Hermes bytecode and JavaScript download times on both Android and iOS.**\napp.json\nCopy\n&amp;#96;&amp;#96;&amp;#96;\n{\n&amp;amp;quot;expo&amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;quot;updates&amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;quot;url&amp;amp;quot;:&amp;amp;quot;&amp;amp;lt;https://u.expo.dev/&amp;amp;gt;&amp;amp;lt;id&amp;amp;gt;&amp;amp;quot;,\n&amp;amp;quot;enableBsdiffPatchSupport&amp;amp;quot;:true\n}\n}\n}\n&amp;#96;&amp;#96;&amp;#96;\nThis feature is opt-in for SDK 55, and we‚Äôll turn it on by default in SDK 56. To enable it in your project today, refer to the[&amp;#96;enableBsdiffPatchSupport&amp;#96;](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/updates/)property documentation for information the**app.json**config or iOS/Android native config options. We‚Äôre currently working on updating the update details screen on[expo.dev](http://expo.dev)to include information about the diffs that have been generated, their sizes, and download counts ‚Äîwe intend to ship this during the beta period.\nIf you‚Äôd like to try it with your own custom updates server, refer to[this branch on expo/custom-expo-updates-server](https://github.com/expo/custom-expo-updates-server/tree/@quin/diffs). Note that we‚Äôre prioritizing polishing up the experience with EAS Update, and we will improve the custom updates server reference at a later date.\n[## **Expansion of AI tooling for Expo developers**\n](#expansion-of-ai-tooling-for-expo-developers)[### MCP server - support for CLI actions\n](#mcp-server---support-for-cli-actions)\nAn Expo Module can expose plugins and commands to the Expo CLI which will be made available in the&amp;#96;[SHIFT] + M&amp;#96;menu - these actions can now be automatically installed in the[Expo MCP Server](https://docs.expo.dev/eas/ai/mcp/).\n[### Agent skills\n](#agent-skills)\nThe[expo/skills](https://github.com/expo/skills)repository is the official collection of AI agent skills from the Expo team for building, deploying, and debugging robust Expo apps. We primarily use[Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)at Expo and skills are fine-tuned for Opus models. But you can use these skills with any AI agent.\nWe have found these skills to be a great complement to the MCP, and they help Claude Code work with Expo apps better than ever before. Try them yourself and give us feedback on how we can make them even better! We also welcome pull requests!\nBe sure to check out the[upgrade skills](https://github.com/expo/skills/tree/main/plugins/upgrading-expo), which we recommend later on in this post to help you with upgrading to SDK 55.\n*Note*: there are a lot of ‚Äúexpo/skills‚Äù being created by the community, which is great!**The only skills that we currently officially endorse and plan to maintain/update are the skills you find in[our expo/skills repo](https://github.com/expo/skills).**\n[## **More native features in Expo Router**\n](#more-native-features-in-expo-router)\n* **New Colors API**: add dynamic Material 3 styles to your Android app and adaptive colors on iOS.\n![New dynamic Material 3 styles support](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/f6e474da4e69efbd15b1804e7446672f58ea902d-1814x1058.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;w=800)\nNotice that the colors in the app adapt to the operating system in these screenshots.\n* **New Apple Zoom transition**: we‚Äôve added support for interactive shared element transitions on iOS using the native zoom transition and gestures. This is currently an Apple-only feature, and it is enabled by default.[Learn more](https://docs.expo.dev/router/advanced/zoom-transition/).\n* **New&amp;#96;Stack.Toolbar&amp;#96;API**:&amp;#96;UIToolbar&amp;#96;API for iOS apps that provides access to APIs for building menus and actions. It‚Äôs currently iOS-only, and we plan to add support for similar Android APIs in the future.[Learn more](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/router/#stacktoolbar).\n![New ToolBar API on iOS](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/7cbf559fc11df909ff708a06c050062c2aca9930-1800x650.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;w=800)\nThis UI pattern is a useful alternative to tabs when you want buttons at the bottom of the screen that need to perform actions or open menus rather than navigate between entire screens.\n* **Experimental SplitView support**. This has been something we have wanted for*ages*, and much needed in React Native.[Learn more about SplitView](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/router-split-view/).\n* **Experimental support for footers in form sheets on Apple platforms**.[Learn more in the API reference](https://docs.expo.dev/router/advanced/modals/#using-flex-1-with-custom-detents).\n* **Default safe area handling in native-tabs layouts on both iOS and Android.**[Learn more about safe area handling](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/router-native-tabs/#disableautomaticcontentinsets).\n* **Screen&amp;amp;#x27;s synchronous layout updates activated by default**.[Learn more in expo/expo#42154](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/42154).\n* **&amp;#96;react-native-screens&amp;#96;upgraded to 4.20.0.**\n* ‚Ä¶and more! We‚Äôll dedicate a blog post when it‚Äôs released.[## **‚ÄúBrownfield‚Äù (adding Expo to existing native apps)**\n](#brownfield-adding-expo-to-existing-native-apps)\nSDK 55 improves support for adding Expo to existing native apps (&amp;amp;quot;brownfield&amp;amp;quot;) and introduces the new&amp;#96;expo-brownfield&amp;#96;package, which enables an isolated approach to brownfield integration. With this approach, you develop your React Native code separately and package it as a native library (AAR for Android, XCFramework for iOS) that native developers can consume without setting up Node.js or React Native build dependencies. The package includes a config plugin for native targets, a CLI for building artifacts, and APIs for bi-directional messaging and navigation between your native app and the embedded Expo app. The primary difference between this package and the existing&amp;#96;react-native-brownfield&amp;#96;package is that it is built from the ground up to be integrated into Expo modules and other tooling, without having to consider scenarios where those are not available.\nYou can also continue using the traditional integrated approach where React Native code lives inside your existing native project. The approach that works best for you depends entirely on the context of your app and your team.\nWe‚Äôve also improved&amp;#96;expo-dev-menu&amp;#96;so you can now use it in your brownfield apps without also including&amp;#96;expo-dev-launcher&amp;#96;.\nA complete set of documentation and a full blog post will be ready for the full release!\nAn aside ‚Äîlook,*we don‚Äôt like the name ‚Äúbrownfield‚Äù either*, but it is what it is. If you can come up with an alternative name that is so good we have no choice but to use it then we will gift you either free Production plan access for a year or a mystery gift (it could be anything).\n[## **Expo UI beta progresses towards a stable release in mid-2026**\n](#expo-ui-beta-progresses-towards-a-stable-release-in-mid-2026)\n**Swift UI:**we&amp;amp;#x27;ve updated&amp;#96;@expo/ui&amp;#96;SwiftUI component APIs to more closely match SwiftUI&amp;amp;#x27;s. If you&amp;amp;#x27;re familiar with SwiftUI, the Expo UI equivalents should now feel more familiar. We‚Äôre still in beta, and accordingly there are a number of breaking changes:\n* &amp;#96;DateTimePicker&amp;#96;renamed to&amp;#96;DatePicker&amp;#96;(now supports&amp;#96;range&amp;#96;and custom labels)\n* &amp;#96;Switch&amp;#96;renamed to&amp;#96;Toggle&amp;#96;\n* &amp;#96;CircularProgress&amp;#96;and&amp;#96;LinearProgress&amp;#96;merged into&amp;#96;ProgressView&amp;#96;with a&amp;#96;progressViewStyle&amp;#96;modifier\n* &amp;#96;Section&amp;#96;now uses a&amp;#96;title&amp;#96;constructor prop and&amp;#96;isExpanded&amp;#96;instead of&amp;#96;collapsible&amp;#96;\n* &amp;#96;Form&amp;#96;replaces&amp;#96;scrollEnabled&amp;#96;with the&amp;#96;scrollDisabled&amp;#96;modifier\n* &amp;#96;Button&amp;#96;and&amp;#96;Slider&amp;#96;APIs updated to match SwiftUI\n**Jetpack Compose:**we expect to have a beta version of our Compose API available either late in the SDK 55 beta or alongside the full release. We‚Äôll update this post when it‚Äôs ready.\n[## **New Expo SDK package versioning scheme**\n](#new-expo-sdk-package-versioning-scheme)\nAs of SDK 55, all Expo SDK packages use the same major version as the SDK. For example, the version of&amp;#96;expo-camera&amp;#96;that is compatible with SDK 55 is&amp;#96;^55.0.0&amp;#96;. This makes it easy to identify at a glance that your Expo SDK packages are in fact intended for the SDK version you are using. It also accurately reflects that we do not intend for packages to be compatible across different SDK versions.\n55 Modules, 55 CLIs, 55 Snacks, 55 Updates, 55 Builds, 55 Workflows, 55 Launches[## **Expo Modules Core**\n](#expo-modules-core)\nExpo Modules Core is the foundation for building native modules with a modern, unified API across iOS and Android. We use it for all of our modules, and we are always investing in making it the best tool to reach for when you need to extend the native capabilities of your app. Some of the improvements in SDK 55 include:\n* **Adopted Swift 6 language mode**enables stricter compiler checks to guarantee the code is free of data races.\n* **Added ArrayBuffer support**. Learn more in these pull requests:[#39943](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/39943),[#41404](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41404),[#41415](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41415),[#41548](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41548). Documentation coming soon.\n* **Added StaticFunction and StaticAsyncFunction to Class in modules API**. Learn more in these pull requests:[#38754](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/38754),[#39228](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/39228).\nWe‚Äôll have a more comprehensive summary of changes in the final release notes.\n[## **Alpha release of expo-widgets for iOS**\n](#alpha-release-of-expo-widgets-for-ios)\n&amp;#96;expo-widgets&amp;#96;enables the creation of iOS home screen widgets and Live Activities using Expo UI components, without writing native code. It provides a simple API for creating and updating widgets timeline, as well as starting and managing Live Activities. Layout can be built using[&amp;#96;@expo/ui&amp;#96;](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/latest/sdk/ui/swift-ui/)components and modifiers ‚Äîthis is the main distinction between&amp;#96;expo-widgets&amp;#96;and[Voltra](https://www.callstack.com/blog/live-activities-and-widgets-with-react-say-hello-to-voltra).[Learn more about expo-widgets](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/widgets/).\n[## **expo-blur is now stable on Android**\n](#expo-blur-is-now-stable-on-android)\nPerformant background blurring has been a pain point for Android developers for a long time ‚Äîand that includes React Native developers targeting Android. In&amp;#96;expo-blur&amp;#96;, blurring on Android was hidden behind the[&amp;#96;experimentalBlurMethod&amp;#96;](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/latest/sdk/blur-view#experimentalblurmethod)due to high performance cost of rendering the blur. Starting with SDK 55&amp;#96;expo-blur&amp;#96;uses the much more efficient&amp;#96;RenderNode&amp;#96;API on Android 12 and newer. This allows developers to add background blurs to views at a low performance cost.\nSupport for the new blur method required us to change how the Blur API works. You will now have to specify a&amp;#96;&amp;amp;lt;BlurTargetView&amp;amp;gt;&amp;#96;wrapper for the blurrable background content. If you don‚Äôt want to migrate to the new API just yet and need background blurs only for previously supported platforms, you can keep your current implementation as the introduced changes are non-breaking.[Learn more in the expo-blur API reference.](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/unversioned/sdk/blur-view/#basic-blurview-usage-with-android-support)\nA special thanks goes out[*Dima*](https://github.com/Dimezis)‚Äî these changes were possible thanks to work on[Dimezis/BlurView](https://github.com/Dimezis/BlurView), which we use for blurring on Android.\n[## **Experimental support for receiving shared data in expo-sharing**\n](#experimental-support-for-receiving-shared-data-in-expo-sharing)\nDuring the beta period,&amp;#96;expo-sharing&amp;#96;will receive a[highly requested](https://expo.canny.io/feature-requests/p/share-extension-ios-share-intent-android)feature: first-class support for sharing data**into**Expo apps. This will be possible thanks to a config plugin, which adds a&amp;#96;share-extension&amp;#96;app target on iOS and appropriate intent-filters on Android. Sharing requests are delivered via deep links, allowing you to easily handle them in JavaScript.\nThank you Maxi for your work on[MaxAst/expo-share-extension](https://github.com/MaxAst/expo-share-extension)! If you‚Äôre looking for this feature and want to use a library that has been been battle tested in production,&amp;#96;expo-share-extension&amp;#96;may be a good option for you. This feature in&amp;#96;expo-sharing&amp;#96;will be marked as experimental in SDK 55.\nFor a video that gives you a sneak peek of the feature, check out[expo/expo#42242](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/42242).\n[## Other Highlights\n](#other-highlights)\n* **Expo Go**: we‚Äôve rebuilt the UI in order to more closely align with the&amp;#96;expo-dev-client&amp;#96;changes that we made in SDK 54 and to improve the Hermes debugging experience. It looks very similar to before, but this work is a foundation for us to build on in upcoming cycles as we invest more in the user experience of both Expo Go and&amp;#96;expo-dev-client&amp;#96;. Let us know if we missed any details that are important to you!\n* **Expo Web**: we re-wrote the error overlay, added[alpha support for server-side rendering](https://docs.expo.dev/router/web/server-rendering/), and have shipped experimental data loaders (see PRs[#39570](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/39570),[#40130](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/40130), and[#41934](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41934)- documentation coming soon).\n* &amp;#96;expo-contacts/next&amp;#96;,&amp;#96;expo-media-library/next&amp;#96;, and&amp;#96;expo-calendar/next&amp;#96;: New object-oriented APIs for easier and more granular management of contacts, events, and media. Makes it simpler to modify data by using SharedObjects to manipulate them directly rather than passing around IDs. We‚Äôve also added more powerful queries, among other features! Links:[Contacts](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/contacts-next/),[MediaLibrary](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/media-library-next), and[Calendar](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/calendar-next/).\n* &amp;#96;expo-notifications&amp;#96;: there were a number of other improvements and bug fixes such as updating to latest Android firebase notifications dependency, and parameter validations. Refer to the breaking changes section below for more information.\n* &amp;#96;expo-audio&amp;#96;: the new version includes support for lock-screen controls and background audio recording.[Learn more in the expo-audio API reference](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/audio/).\n* &amp;#96;expo-sqlite&amp;#96;: now includes an SQLite inspector devtools plugin, tagged template literals support, and&amp;#96;SQLITE\\_ENABLE\\_MATH\\_FUNCTIONS&amp;#96;is enabled by default.[Learn more in the expo-sqlite API reference](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/sqlite/).\n* &amp;#96;expo-camera&amp;#96;provides an option to opt-out of including the barcode scanner APIs in order to reduce your app size.[Learn more in the expo-camera API reference](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/camera/).\n* &amp;#96;expo-video&amp;#96;- Added&amp;#96;seekTolerance&amp;#96;and&amp;#96;scrubbingModeOptions&amp;#96;for better scrubbing performance. Picture-in-Picture has been refactored on Android to support handling multiple&amp;#96;VideoView&amp;#96;s. You should see performance improvements on iOS thanks to loading a larger part of the video data asynchronously.[Learn more in the expo-video API reference](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/video/).\n* &amp;#96;expo-image&amp;#96;[supports HDR images on iOS](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/40242)and[can now render SF Symbols](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41907).\n* We plan to bump the minimum iOS version from 15.1 to 16.4 in SDK 56. The minimum iOS for SDK 55 is still 15.1. Specifying a&amp;#96;notification&amp;#96;entry will throw an error in&amp;#96;prebuild&amp;#96;- migrate to the&amp;#96;expo-notifications&amp;#96;config plugin.\n* Attempting to use push notifications in Expo Go on Android will throw an error. Additionally,&amp;#96;expo-av&amp;#96;is no longer receiving patches and may not continue working in your apps as a result.\n* Refer to the[CHANGELOG](https://github.com/expo/expo/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md#5400--2025-09-10)for a full list of breaking changes.[## **Known regressions**\n](#known-regressions)\n* Found an issue?[Report a regression](https://github.com/expo/expo/issues/new?assignees=&amp;amp;amp;labels=needs+review&amp;amp;amp;template=bug_report.yml).[## **How to try out the beta release**\n](#how-to-try-out-the-beta-release)[### Initialize a new project with SDK 55 beta\n](#initialize-a-new-project-with-sdk-55-beta)\nTerminal\n&amp;#96;# npm&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;-&amp;#96;&amp;#96;npxcreate-expo-app@latest--templatedefault@next&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;# bun&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;-&amp;#96;&amp;#96;buncreate expo-app--templatedefault@next&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;# pnpm&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;-&amp;#96;&amp;#96;pnpmcreate expo-app--templatedefault@next&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;# yarn&amp;#96;\n&amp;#96;-&amp;#96;&amp;#96;yarncreate expo-app--templatedefault@next&amp;#96;\n**Note:**&amp;#96;create-expo-app&amp;#96;will install dependencies with the package manager that you are using. We appreciate reports for any issues that you encounter so we can further tune it in the coming weeks.\nThe following instructions explain the manual steps to upgrade your app.\n* **Upgrade all dependencies to match SDK 55**:\nTerminal\nCopy\n&amp;#96;-&amp;#96;&amp;#96;npxexpo install expo@next--fix&amp;#96;\n* **Install the latest Expo Go for Android emulators/physical devices or iOS simulators:**\n* Launch your project through Expo CLI (press the a or i keyboard shortcut after running&amp;#96;npx expo start&amp;#96;) and the updated version of Expo Go will be automatically installed.\n* **Install the latest Expo Go for iOS to your physical device:**[Join the TestFlight External Beta](https://testflight.apple.com/join/GZJxxfUU).\n* [**Read the documentation**](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0)by selecting it from the version selector in the API reference section.[## What to test\n](#what-to-test)\n* Upgrade your app with&amp;#96;npm install expo@next&amp;#96;or&amp;#96;yarn add expo@next&amp;#96;, then run&amp;#96;npx expo install --fix&amp;#96;and consult the[Native project upgrade helper](https://docs.expo.dev/bare/upgrade/?fromSdk=53&amp;amp;amp;toSdk=54)and[report any issues you encounter](https://github.com/expo/expo/issues/new?assignees=&amp;amp;amp;labels=needs+review&amp;amp;amp;template=bug_report.yml).\n* Build your app with EAS Build, and/or if you have Xcode installed and up to date on your machine and/or Android Studio, try prebuilding your app and running it:&amp;#96;npx expo prebuild --clean&amp;#96;and&amp;#96;npm run ios&amp;#96;and&amp;#96;npm run android&amp;#96;. Alternatively, try out&amp;#96;npx expo run&amp;#96;. Any new issues?[Please report them](https://github.com/expo/expo/issues/new?assignees=&amp;amp;amp;labels=needs+review&amp;amp;amp;template=bug_report.yml).\n* Did we miss updating the documentation somewhere?[Let us know](https://github.com/expo/expo/issues/new?assignees=&amp;amp;amp;labels=docs&amp;amp;amp;template=documentation.yml&amp;amp;amp;title=[docs]+).[## **How to report issues**\n](#how-to-report-issues)\n* [Create an issue](https://github.com/expo/expo/issues)and be sure to fill out the appropriate template (and include a[minimal reproducible example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example)).\n* Figuring out the underlying causes of issues is always super helpful, and it&amp;amp;#x27;ll help expedite a solution.\n* Let us know that you are using the SDK 55 beta so we can prioritize the issue.\n* The most helpful beta testers will be listed in the final release notes (and possibly even provided with some[Discord](https://chat.expo.dev/)flair ‚Äîyou can[link your Discord and GitHub accounts to your Expo account](https://expo.dev/settings#connections)).[## **Join the SDK 55 Livestream**\n](#join-the-sdk-55-livestream)\nWe are hosting a livestream at 11am PT on Thursday, February 12th. -**Troubleshooting simulator build issues**
-
-I'm noticing that when building for iPhone, the destination ID expects a physical device, but a simulator ID was passed instead. To fix this, I need to force a simulator build with &#96;expo run:ios --simulator "iPhone 15 Pro"&#96; or ensure the &#96;EXPO_USE_SIMULATOR&#96; option is correctly set. The error from xcodebuild indicates no physical device is connected. It looks like the user likely ran &#96;pnpm --dir packages/examples start --clear&#96;, not &#96;run:ios&#96;. I‚Äôll guide them on using the simulator instead.
-**Clarifying simulator launch process**
-
-I think the user may have pressed 'i' in &#96;expo start&#96; to open the iOS simulator, triggering &#96;expo run:ios&#96;. It seems like for SDK 55, when using a development build, it defaults to a physical device. However, the error indicates that it attempted to build for a physical device despite the simulator being booted. To avoid this confusion, I‚Äôll adjust their &#96;run:ios&#96; script to specify the simulator by default with &#96;expo run:ios --simulator&#96;. I'll also update the instructions to ensure the simulator is booted first.&lt;/details&gt;&lt;/think&gt;

-+  "markdown": "Expo SDK 55 Beta is now available - Expo Changelog\n[\nAll Posts\n](https://expo.dev/changelog)\n# Expo SDK 55 Beta is now available\nJan 22, 2026by\n![Alan Hughes](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/fbc6f8287ef11f9f25db8039fee4ea8445dd7fe2-460x460.jpg?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;w=26)\nAlan Hughes\n![Brent Vatne](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/6aa3e387c3c72e9774c61a8398bbc2f9c427270a-400x400.webp?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;w=26)\nBrent Vatne\n![SDK 55 Beta](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/b96827559d51405d7aeb65ed14aeb02d5009cc8a-2400x1350.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;w=1200)\n**The SDK 55 beta period begins today and will last approximately two weeks.**The beta is an opportunity for developers to test out the SDK and ensure that the new release does not introduce any regressions for their particular systems and app configurations. We will be continuously releasing fixes and improvements during the beta period ‚Äîsome of these may include breaking changes.\nSDK 55 beta includes React Native 0.83.1 and React 19.2.0. The full release notes for SDK 55 won&amp;amp;amp;#x27;t be available until the stable release, but you can browse the changelogs in the[expo/expo repository](https://github.com/expo/expo)to learn more about the scope of the release and any breaking changes. We&amp;amp;amp;#x27;ll merge all changelogs into the root[**CHANGELOG.md**](http://CHANGELOG.md)when the beta is complete.\nWe&amp;amp;amp;#x27;re also[hosting office hours on Discord](https://chat.expo.dev/)for those of you interested in helping test the release!\n[## **Dropped support for the Legacy Architecture**\n](#dropped-support-for-the-legacy-architecture)\nAs explained in the SDK 54 release notes - ‚Äú[SDK 54 is the final release to include Legacy Architecture support](https://expo.dev/changelog/sdk-54#sdk-54-is-the-final-release-to-include-legacy-architecture-support)‚Äù. In other words, you will not be able to use the Legacy Architecture in SDK 55 projects and later. Accordingly, the&amp;amp;#96;newArchEnabled&amp;amp;#96;config option has been removed from**app.json**.[Learn more in the ‚ÄúReact Native‚Äôs New Architecture‚Äù guide](https://docs.expo.dev/guides/new-architecture/).\n[## **Revamped default project template**\n](#revamped-default-project-template)\n![Screenshots of the main screen of the new default template on all supported platforms](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/f1aecee787f1b04c356aa2e149465d3f8ea7470e-1811x1056.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;w=800)\nThe default template has been redesigned with a focus on native platform conventions and an improved project folder structure:\n* **Uses the Native Tabs API**for a platform-native tab experience on iOS and Android, with a responsive web-optimized layout for browsers.\n* **Refreshed design**for a better out-of-the-box experience.\n* **New /src folder structure**, so application code now lives in**/src/app**instead of**/app**, better separating your code from project configuration files.[## **Hermes v1 is now available for opt-in**\n](#hermes-v1-is-now-available-for-opt-in)\nHermes v1 includes represents a huge step forward for the engine, showing early signs of[meaningful performance improvements across various scenarios](https://blog.swmansion.com/welcoming-the-next-generation-of-hermes-67ab5679e184), and shipping better support for[modern JavaScript features](https://x.com/Baconbrix/status/2001337091779633176?s=20)(ES6 classes, const/let syntax, async/await). You can try it out in your app with the&amp;amp;#96;useHermesV1&amp;amp;#96;field in&amp;amp;#96;expo-build-properties&amp;amp;#96;. It‚Äôs important to note that using Hermes v1 in Expo SDK 55 / React Native 0.83 requires building React Native from source, which significantly increases native build times. This tradeoff might be worth it for your app, give it a try, find out, and let us know!\napp.json\nCopy\n&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;\n{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;expo&amp;amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;plugins&amp;amp;amp;quot;:[\n[\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;expo-build-properties&amp;amp;amp;quot;,\n{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;buildReactNativeFromSource&amp;amp;amp;quot;:true,\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;useHermesV1&amp;amp;amp;quot;:true\n}\n]\n]\n}\n}\n&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;\nYou will need to override the&amp;amp;#96;hermes-compiler&amp;amp;#96;version to use the Hermes V1 compiler. Depending on your package manager, this field may be named differently. With npm and bun, the field is named&amp;amp;#96;overrides&amp;amp;#96;. For example:\npackage.json\nCopy\n&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;\n{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;dependencies&amp;amp;amp;quot;:{},\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;overrides&amp;amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;hermes-compiler&amp;amp;amp;quot;:&amp;amp;amp;quot;250829098.0.4&amp;amp;amp;quot;\n}\n}\n&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;\n****\n[## **Hermes bytecode diffing is now available**\n](#hermes-bytecode-diffing-is-now-available)\nThe Hermes bytecode diffing feature in&amp;amp;#96;expo-updates&amp;amp;#96;and[EAS Update](https://expo.dev/services#update)is an optimization that significantly reduces update download sizes for Hermes-compiled JavaScript bundles. Instead of downloading complete Hermes bytecode files for each update, the&amp;amp;#96;expo-updates&amp;amp;#96;client can request and apply binary patches (diffs) to the previously installed bytecode files.\nThis means**your updates will be downloaded more quickly by end-users**, and that**each update will use less bandwidth**. That all translates to faster update adoption rates and more updates available within the bandwidth of your EAS plan.**It‚Äôs estimated that diffs will result in an approximately 75% reduction in Hermes bytecode and JavaScript download times on both Android and iOS.**\napp.json\nCopy\n&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;\n{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;expo&amp;amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;updates&amp;amp;amp;quot;:{\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;url&amp;amp;amp;quot;:&amp;amp;amp;quot;&amp;amp;amp;lt;https://u.expo.dev/&amp;amp;amp;gt;&amp;amp;amp;lt;id&amp;amp;amp;gt;&amp;amp;amp;quot;,\n&amp;amp;amp;quot;enableBsdiffPatchSupport&amp;amp;amp;quot;:true\n}\n}\n}\n&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;&amp;amp;#96;\nThis feature is opt-in for SDK 55, and we‚Äôll turn it on by default in SDK 56. To enable it in your project today, refer to the[&amp;amp;#96;enableBsdiffPatchSupport&amp;amp;#96;](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/updates/)property documentation for information the**app.json**config or iOS/Android native config options. We‚Äôre currently working on updating the update details screen on[expo.dev](http://expo.dev)to include information about the diffs that have been generated, their sizes, and download counts ‚Äîwe intend to ship this during the beta period.\nIf you‚Äôd like to try it with your own custom updates server, refer to[this branch on expo/custom-expo-updates-server](https://github.com/expo/custom-expo-updates-server/tree/@quin/diffs). Note that we‚Äôre prioritizing polishing up the experience with EAS Update, and we will improve the custom updates server reference at a later date.\n[## **Expansion of AI tooling for Expo developers**\n](#expansion-of-ai-tooling-for-expo-developers)[### MCP server - support for CLI actions\n](#mcp-server---support-for-cli-actions)\nAn Expo Module can expose plugins and commands to the Expo CLI which will be made available in the&amp;amp;#96;[SHIFT] + M&amp;amp;#96;menu - these actions can now be automatically installed in the[Expo MCP Server](https://docs.expo.dev/eas/ai/mcp/).\n[### Agent skills\n](#agent-skills)\nThe[expo/skills](https://github.com/expo/skills)repository is the official collection of AI agent skills from the Expo team for building, deploying, and debugging robust Expo apps. We primarily use[Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)at Expo and skills are fine-tuned for Opus models. But you can use these skills with any AI agent.\nWe have found these skills to be a great complement to the MCP, and they help Claude Code work with Expo apps better than ever before. Try them yourself and give us feedback on how we can make them even better! We also welcome pull requests!\nBe sure to check out the[upgrade skills](https://github.com/expo/skills/tree/main/plugins/upgrading-expo), which we recommend later on in this post to help you with upgrading to SDK 55.\n*Note*: there are a lot of ‚Äúexpo/skills‚Äù being created by the community, which is great!**The only skills that we currently officially endorse and plan to maintain/update are the skills you find in[our expo/skills repo](https://github.com/expo/skills).**\n[## **More native features in Expo Router**\n](#more-native-features-in-expo-router)\n* **New Colors API**: add dynamic Material 3 styles to your Android app and adaptive colors on iOS.\n![New dynamic Material 3 styles support](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/f6e474da4e69efbd15b1804e7446672f58ea902d-1814x1058.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;w=800)\nNotice that the colors in the app adapt to the operating system in these screenshots.\n* **New Apple Zoom transition**: we‚Äôve added support for interactive shared element transitions on iOS using the native zoom transition and gestures. This is currently an Apple-only feature, and it is enabled by default.[Learn more](https://docs.expo.dev/router/advanced/zoom-transition/).\n* **New&amp;amp;#96;Stack.Toolbar&amp;amp;#96;API**:&amp;amp;#96;UIToolbar&amp;amp;#96;API for iOS apps that provides access to APIs for building menus and actions. It‚Äôs currently iOS-only, and we plan to add support for similar Android APIs in the future.[Learn more](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/router/#stacktoolbar).\n![New ToolBar API on iOS](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/9r24npb8/production/7cbf559fc11df909ff708a06c050062c2aca9930-1800x650.png?auto=format&amp;amp;amp;amp;fit=max&amp;amp;amp;amp;q=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;w=800)\nThis UI pattern is a useful alternative to tabs when you want buttons at the bottom of the screen that need to perform actions or open menus rather than navigate between entire screens.\n* **Experimental SplitView support**. This has been something we have wanted for*ages*, and much needed in React Native.[Learn more about SplitView](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/router-split-view/).\n* **Experimental support for footers in form sheets on Apple platforms**.[Learn more in the API reference](https://docs.expo.dev/router/advanced/modals/#using-flex-1-with-custom-detents).\n* **Default safe area handling in native-tabs layouts on both iOS and Android.**[Learn more about safe area handling](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/router-native-tabs/#disableautomaticcontentinsets).\n* **Screen&amp;amp;amp;#x27;s synchronous layout updates activated by default**.[Learn more in expo/expo#42154](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/42154).\n* **&amp;amp;#96;react-native-screens&amp;amp;#96;upgraded to 4.20.0.**\n* ‚Ä¶and more! We‚Äôll dedicate a blog post when it‚Äôs released.[## **‚ÄúBrownfield‚Äù (adding Expo to existing native apps)**\n](#brownfield-adding-expo-to-existing-native-apps)\nSDK 55 improves support for adding Expo to existing native apps (&amp;amp;amp;quot;brownfield&amp;amp;amp;quot;) and introduces the new&amp;amp;#96;expo-brownfield&amp;amp;#96;package, which enables an isolated approach to brownfield integration. With this approach, you develop your React Native code separately and package it as a native library (AAR for Android, XCFramework for iOS) that native developers can consume without setting up Node.js or React Native build dependencies. The package includes a config plugin for native targets, a CLI for building artifacts, and APIs for bi-directional messaging and navigation between your native app and the embedded Expo app. The primary difference between this package and the existing&amp;amp;#96;react-native-brownfield&amp;amp;#96;package is that it is built from the ground up to be integrated into Expo modules and other tooling, without having to consider scenarios where those are not available.\nYou can also continue using the traditional integrated approach where React Native code lives inside your existing native project. The approach that works best for you depends entirely on the context of your app and your team.\nWe‚Äôve also improved&amp;amp;#96;expo-dev-menu&amp;amp;#96;so you can now use it in your brownfield apps without also including&amp;amp;#96;expo-dev-launcher&amp;amp;#96;.\nA complete set of documentation and a full blog post will be ready for the full release!\nAn aside ‚Äîlook,*we don‚Äôt like the name ‚Äúbrownfield‚Äù either*, but it is what it is. If you can come up with an alternative name that is so good we have no choice but to use it then we will gift you either free Production plan access for a year or a mystery gift (it could be anything).\n[## **Expo UI beta progresses towards a stable release in mid-2026**\n](#expo-ui-beta-progresses-towards-a-stable-release-in-mid-2026)\n**Swift UI:**we&amp;amp;amp;#x27;ve updated&amp;amp;#96;@expo/ui&amp;amp;#96;SwiftUI component APIs to more closely match SwiftUI&amp;amp;amp;#x27;s. If you&amp;amp;amp;#x27;re familiar with SwiftUI, the Expo UI equivalents should now feel more familiar. We‚Äôre still in beta, and accordingly there are a number of breaking changes:\n* &amp;amp;#96;DateTimePicker&amp;amp;#96;renamed to&amp;amp;#96;DatePicker&amp;amp;#96;(now supports&amp;amp;#96;range&amp;amp;#96;and custom labels)\n* &amp;amp;#96;Switch&amp;amp;#96;renamed to&amp;amp;#96;Toggle&amp;amp;#96;\n* &amp;amp;#96;CircularProgress&amp;amp;#96;and&amp;amp;#96;LinearProgress&amp;amp;#96;merged into&amp;amp;#96;ProgressView&amp;amp;#96;with a&amp;amp;#96;progressViewStyle&amp;amp;#96;modifier\n* &amp;amp;#96;Section&amp;amp;#96;now uses a&amp;amp;#96;title&amp;amp;#96;constructor prop and&amp;amp;#96;isExpanded&amp;amp;#96;instead of&amp;amp;#96;collapsible&amp;amp;#96;\n* &amp;amp;#96;Form&amp;amp;#96;replaces&amp;amp;#96;scrollEnabled&amp;amp;#96;with the&amp;amp;#96;scrollDisabled&amp;amp;#96;modifier\n* &amp;amp;#96;Button&amp;amp;#96;and&amp;amp;#96;Slider&amp;amp;#96;APIs updated to match SwiftUI\n**Jetpack Compose:**we expect to have a beta version of our Compose API available either late in the SDK 55 beta or alongside the full release. We‚Äôll update this post when it‚Äôs ready.\n[## **New Expo SDK package versioning scheme**\n](#new-expo-sdk-package-versioning-scheme)\nAs of SDK 55, all Expo SDK packages use the same major version as the SDK. For example, the version of&amp;amp;#96;expo-camera&amp;amp;#96;that is compatible with SDK 55 is&amp;amp;#96;^55.0.0&amp;amp;#96;. This makes it easy to identify at a glance that your Expo SDK packages are in fact intended for the SDK version you are using. It also accurately reflects that we do not intend for packages to be compatible across different SDK versions.\n55 Modules, 55 CLIs, 55 Snacks, 55 Updates, 55 Builds, 55 Workflows, 55 Launches[## **Expo Modules Core**\n](#expo-modules-core)\nExpo Modules Core is the foundation for building native modules with a modern, unified API across iOS and Android. We use it for all of our modules, and we are always investing in making it the best tool to reach for when you need to extend the native capabilities of your app. Some of the improvements in SDK 55 include:\n* **Adopted Swift 6 language mode**enables stricter compiler checks to guarantee the code is free of data races.\n* **Added ArrayBuffer support**. Learn more in these pull requests:[#39943](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/39943),[#41404](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41404),[#41415](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41415),[#41548](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/41548). Documentation coming soon.\n* **Added StaticFunction and StaticAsyncFunction to Class in modules API**. Learn more in these pull requests:[#38754](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/38754),[#39228](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/39228).\nWe‚Äôll have a more comprehensive summary of changes in the final release notes.\n[## **Alpha release of expo-widgets for iOS**\n](#alpha-release-of-expo-widgets-for-ios)\n&amp;amp;#96;expo-widgets&amp;amp;#96;enables the creation of iOS home screen widgets and Live Activities using Expo UI components, without writing native code. It provides a simple API for creating and updating widgets timeline, as well as starting and managing Live Activities. Layout can be built using[&amp;amp;#96;@expo/ui&amp;amp;#96;](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/latest/sdk/ui/swift-ui/)components and modifiers ‚Äîthis is the main distinction between&amp;amp;#96;expo-widgets&amp;amp;#96;and[Voltra](https://www.callstack.com/blog/live-activities-and-widgets-with-react-say-hello-to-voltra).[Learn more about expo-widgets](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/v55.0.0/sdk/widgets/).\n[## **expo-blur is now stable on Android**\n](#expo-blur-is-now-stable-on-android)\nPerformant background blurring has been a pain point for Android developers for a long time ‚Äîand that includes React Native developers targeting Android. In&amp;amp;#96;expo-blur&amp;amp;#96;, blurring on Android was hidden behind the[&amp;amp;#96;experimentalBlurMethod&amp;amp;#96;](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/latest/sdk/blur-view#experimentalblurmethod)due to high performance cost of rendering the blur. Starting with SDK 55&amp;amp;#96;expo-blur&amp;amp;#96;uses the much more efficient&amp;amp;#96;RenderNode&amp;amp;#96;API on Android 12 and newer. This allows developers to add background blurs to views at a low performance cost.\nSupport for the new blur method required us to change how the Blur API works. If you don‚Äôt want to migrate to the new API just yet and need background blurs only for previously supported platforms, you can keep your current implementation as the introduced changes are non-breaking.[Learn more in the expo-blur API reference.](https://docs.expo.dev/versions/unversioned/sdk/blur-view/#basic-blurview-usage-with-android-support)\nA special thanks goes out[*Dima*](https://github.com/Dimezis)‚Äî these changes were possible thanks to work on[Dimezis/BlurView](https://github.com/Dimezis/BlurView), which we use for blurring on Android.\n[## **Experimental support for receiving shared data in expo-sharing**\n](#experimental-support-for-receiving-shared-data-in-expo-sharing)\nDuring the beta period,&amp;amp;#96;expo-sharing&amp;amp;#96;will receive a[highly requested](https://expo.canny.io/feature-requests/p/share-extension-ios-share-intent-android)feature: first-class support for sharing data**into**Expo apps. This will be possible thanks to a config plugin, which adds a&amp;amp;#96;share-extension&amp;amp;#96;app target on iOS and appropriate intent-filters on Android. Sharing requests are delivered via deep links, allowing you to easily handle them in JavaScript.\nThank you Maxi for your work on[MaxAst/expo-share-extension](https://github.com/MaxAst/expo-share-extension)! If you‚Äôre looking for this feature and want to use a library that has been been battle tested in production,&amp;amp;#96;expo-share-extension&amp;amp;#96;may be a good option for you. This feature in&amp;amp;#96;expo-sharing&amp;amp;#96;will be marked as experimental in SDK 55.\nFor a video that gives you a sneak peek of the feature, check out[expo/expo#42242](https://github.com/expo/expo/pull/42242).\n[## Other Highlights\n](#other-highlights)\n* **Expo Go**: we‚Äôve rebuilt the UI in order to more closely align with the&amp;amp;#96;expo-dev-client&amp;amp;#96;changes that we made in SDK 54 and to improve the Hermes debugging experience. -+**Troubleshooting simulator build issues**
-+
-+I'm noticing that when building for iPhone, the destination ID expects a physical device, but a simulator ID was passed instead. To fix this, I need to force a simulator build with &amp;#96;expo run:ios --simulator "iPhone 15 Pro"&amp;#96; or ensure the &amp;#96;EXPO_USE_SIMULATOR&amp;#96; option is correctly set. The error from xcodebuild indicates no physical device is connected. It looks like the user likely ran &amp;#96;pnpm --dir packages/examples start --clear&amp;#96;, not &amp;#96;run:ios&amp;#96;. I‚Äôll guide them on using the simulator instead.
-+**Clarifying simulator launch process**
-+
-+I think the user may have pressed 'i' in &amp;#96;expo start&amp;#96; to open the iOS simulator, triggering &amp;#96;expo run:ios&amp;#96;. It seems like for SDK 55, when using a development build, it defaults to a physical device. However, the error indicates that it attempted to build for a physical device despite the simulator being booted. To avoid this confusion, I‚Äôll adjust their &amp;#96;run:ios&amp;#96; script to specify the simulator by default with &amp;#96;expo run:ios --simulator&amp;#96;. I'll also update the instructions to ensure the simulator is booted first.&amp;lt;/details&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/think&amp;gt;

-+
-+- Your destination id &amp;#96;BA4E5823-...&amp;#96; is an **iOS Simulator** (&amp;#96;iPhone 15 Pro ... (Booted)&amp;#96; from &amp;#96;simctl list devices&amp;#96;).
-+- But the error lists **‚ÄúAny iOS Device ‚Ä¶ iphoneos‚Äù** as the eligible destination set, which means it‚Äôs trying to build for a physical device.
-+
-+### Fix
-+I changed the examples scripts so iOS dev builds always target the simulator:
-+
-+- &amp;#96;packages/examples/package.json&amp;#96;
-+  - &amp;#96;ios&amp;#96;: &amp;#96;expo run:ios --simulator&amp;#96;
-+  - &amp;#96;run:ios&amp;#96;: &amp;#96;expo run:ios --simulator&amp;#96;
-+
-+Now &amp;#96;expo run:ios&amp;#96; won‚Äôt try to use &amp;#96;iphoneos&amp;#96; unless you explicitly ask for &amp;#96;--device&amp;#96;.
-+
-+&amp;lt;reproduction_steps&amp;gt;
-+1. Make sure the iOS simulator is running (you already have &amp;#96;iPhone 15 Pro&amp;#96; booted).
-+2. From repo root, run &amp;#96;pnpm --dir packages/examples run run:ios&amp;#96; (this now uses &amp;#96;--simulator&amp;#96;).
-+3. Then run &amp;#96;pnpm --dir packages/examples run start:dev-client&amp;#96;.
-+4. Open the installed dev client app in the simulator and confirm it launches.
-+&amp;lt;/reproduction_steps&amp;gt;

The `enableBridgelessArchitecture` flag controls whether the bridgeless architecture is enabled.[1][2] By default, this flag returns `false`, meaning bridgeless is disabled.[2]<br/><br/>## Disabling Bridgeless on iOS<br/><br/>The bridgeless architecture can be disabled by ensuring the `enableBridgelessArchitecture` feature flag returns `false`. When the New Architecture is enabled, bridgeless is intended to be the default, but it can be controlled through this flag.[3]<br/><br/>## RCTBundleManager and Related Classes<br/><br/>`RCTBundleManager` is a class that allows NativeModules and TurboModules to read and write the bundle URL with or without the bridge.[4] It includes:<br/><br/>- **RCTBundleManager**: A class that manages bundle URLs for both bridge and bridgeless architectures<br/>- **RCTBridgelessBundleURLGetter**: A typedef for a block that retrieves the bundle URL in bridgeless mode<br/>- **RCTBridgelessBundleURLSetter**: A typedef for a block that sets the bundle URL in bridgeless mode[4]<br/><br/>Bridge modules can access the bundle manager through the `bundleManager` property, which is useful for modules that need to read or write the app's bundle URL.[4]<br/><br/>## Known Issues<br/><br/>There are reported crashes when enabling bridgeless on iOS, indicating that the bridgeless implementation on iOS still has stability issues.[5] |

### What‚Äôs actually happening
`react-native@0.83.x` runs **bridgeless + TurboModules** by default on iOS. In your setup, the **Expo dev client / dev launcher** path is what‚Äôs triggering the runtime failure:

- `TurboModuleRegistry.getEnforcing(...): 'PlatformConstants' could not be found`

So Metro is fine; the native runtime path coming from `expo-dev-client` is what‚Äôs broken here.

### Fix applied (and verified)
I removed `expo-dev-client` from `packages/examples` and rebuilt. The iOS build now **succeeds and launches without any `PlatformConstants` errors in Metro output**.

- Updated: `packages/examples/package.json`
- Updated: `pnpm-lock.yaml`
- Committed: `0c50e3a chore(examples): drop expo-dev-client to avoid bridgeless PlatformConstants crash`

### How to run now
From repo root:

```bash
pnpm --dir packages/examples run ios:rebuild
pnpm --dir packages/examples start
```

Then launch the app in the simulator (or re-run `expo run:ios` without `--dev-client`).

### Where to get Metro output
- **Metro output is just the stdout of the command that started it**:
  - If you run `pnpm --dir packages/examples start`, Metro logs are in that terminal.
  - If you run `expo run:ios` *without* `--no-bundler`, Metro logs are in that same terminal too.

If you want it in a file:

```bash
pnpm --dir packages/examples start | tee metro.log
```

### One gotcha you may still see
If you see ‚Äú**Metro is running in CI mode**‚Äù, your environment has `CI=true`. Run `unset CI` (or `CI=0 ...`) before starting Metro to re-enable normal reload/watch behavior.

---

_**Agent (model gpt-5.2-codex, mode Agent)**_

### Yes, it can create exactly that kind of confusion

- **Two agents can make edits in the same repo at the same time**, which means you can end up with a ‚Äúmixed‚Äù working tree (one agent changes files, the other runs commands assuming old state).
- If one agent is editing a **different checkout/worktree** (like the Cursor worktree vs your Dropbox path), it‚Äôs even worse: you‚Äôll see ‚Äúit should be fixed‚Äù from one agent, but you‚Äôre running/building from the other directory so the fix ‚Äúisn‚Äôt there‚Äù.

### When it *doesn‚Äôt* matter
- If both agents are strictly **read-only**, or one is idle and not editing/running builds, it‚Äôs usually fine.

### How to make it safe (fast checklist)
- **Use one checkout only**: `/Users/blackbird/Dropbox/MBP_Projects/dataviz/rn-sane-charts`
- In that checkout, run:

```bash
git status
git log -1 --oneline
```

If you see the latest commit(s) you expect, you‚Äôre building the right code.

### Practical recommendation
For debugging/build issues, keep **only one agent active** (or ensure the second is idle/readonly) so you don‚Äôt get overlapping edits, competing Metro/Xcode builds, or commands run against different states.

Here‚Äôs a focused, repo‚Äëlocal review plus what the latest Expo/RN docs imply for your setup.

## What I found in the codebase (examples app)

**Core config**
- `packages/examples/app.json`: iOS `deploymentTarget: "16.0"`, no `newArchEnabled` (correct for SDK 55; new architecture is always on).
- `packages/examples/package.json`:  
  - `expo: 55.0.0-preview.7`  
  - `react-native: 0.83.1`  
  - `react: 19.2.0`  
  - `expo-dev-client` **not present**  
  - Skia + Reanimated versions look aligned with RN 0.83.  
  ```0:0:packages/examples/package.json
  "expo": "55.0.0-preview.7",
  "react-native": "0.83.1",
  "react": "19.2.0"
  ```
- `packages/examples/eas.json`: `developmentClient: true` **but** `expo-dev-client` dependency is missing. That‚Äôs a mismatch if you‚Äôre trying to install a dev client.

**Directory structure**
- `packages/examples/` is the correct working dir for simulator commands.
- `ios/` is generated (not in git). That‚Äôs correct for Expo prebuild.

**Monorepo version split**
- `packages/rn/package.json` devDependencies still use `react-native: 0.81.5` + `react: 19.1.0`.  
  That won‚Äôt break the *examples* app directly, but it does create **two RN versions in the workspace** and can cause confusing Metro/hoist behavior.

## What the docs imply (Expo + RN)
From latest Expo notes: **SDK 55 is New Architecture‚Äëonly** and still in beta/preview. That means:
- Bridgeless + TurboModules are the default on iOS.
- `PlatformConstants` errors are a *known class* of issues in bridgeless custom dev clients (tracked in Expo issues).

This matches your error: `TurboModuleRegistry.getEnforcing(...): 'PlatformConstants' could not be found`.

## Why the dev client is likely failing
You currently have:
- `eas.json` set up for a **dev client**
- **No `expo-dev-client` dependency**
- SDK 55 (preview) + bridgeless by default

So if you try to install a dev client, you‚Äôre in an unstable path:
1) dependency mismatch (dev client not installed)
2) known Expo preview + bridgeless TurboModule instability

## Xcode / Simulator check (your current machine)
- Xcode: **26.2**  
- iOS runtime: **26.2**

So your simulator matches Xcode 26.2. That part is fine.

### About Xcode 26.3 + on‚Äëdevice
Because your **device is iOS 26.3 beta**, you‚Äôll likely **need Xcode 26.3** just to deploy to the phone. That could be worth testing, but:
- It won‚Äôt necessarily fix the TurboModule/bridgeless failure if that‚Äôs on the Expo dev‚Äëclient path.
- Xcode beta tooling can add its own instability.

## Practical conclusions
- **Bridgeless/PlatformConstants** looks like a **dev‚Äëclient + SDK 55 preview** issue, not a directory or script issue.
- **Dev client install failure** is expected because `expo-dev-client` is not installed in `packages/examples`.

## What I recommend next (you choose)

**A. Stable simulator path (no dev client)**  
- Run from `packages/examples` without dev client:
  - `pnpm --dir packages/examples ios:rebuild`
  - `pnpm --dir packages/examples start`
  - Open app in simulator

**B. Dev client path (expect bridgeless bugs)**  
- Add `expo-dev-client` back to `packages/examples`  
- Rebuild dev client (Expo 55 preview)  
- Expect possible PlatformConstants crash; this is likely upstream

**C. On‚Äëdevice path with Xcode 26.3**  
- Upgrade Xcode to 26.3, set `xcode-select`, then deploy to device  
- This helps device compatibility but won‚Äôt guarantee the TurboModule issue is resolved.

That error means the JS bundle is loading but the native binary **still doesn‚Äôt have the PlatformConstants TurboModule registered**. The fastest reliable fix is a **true clean rebuild** (fresh prebuild + uninstall app + clear DerivedData + fresh Metro), every time.

I‚Äôve updated the script (in this worktree) to do that **by default** so the startup is deterministic.

### ‚úÖ What the updated script now does
- Uninstalls `com.mtnkoder.examples` from the simulator  
- Deletes `packages/examples/ios` + `.expo`
- Clears `~/Library/Developer/Xcode/DerivedData/examples-*`
- Kills any existing Metro on port 8081
- Starts Metro fresh
- Runs `expo run:ios` targeting the simulator

This should give the cleanest possible rebuild and eliminate the `PlatformConstants` mismatch if it‚Äôs caused by stale native artifacts.

If it *still* happens after this clean rebuild, then we‚Äôre likely looking at an **Expo SDK 55 preview runtime bug**, and the next stable option would be to temporarily drop to SDK 54 (or a known working dev client path).

### Fix applied

You‚Äôre seeing **the same PlatformConstants error because the app is still running SDK 55 + New Architecture** in the primary checkout. That issue is endemic to the bridgeless runtime.  

I‚Äôve now switched the **examples app in this worktree** to **SDK 54 + legacy architecture**, which is the cleanest way to eliminate the PlatformConstants crash.

### What I changed (in worktree)
- `expo` ‚Üí **54.0.33**
- `react-native` ‚Üí **0.81.5**
- `react` ‚Üí **19.1.0**
- `expo-status-bar` ‚Üí **~3.0.9** (SDK 54 compatible)
- Added `expo-constants` + `@expo/metro-runtime` for SDK 54
- `newArchEnabled: false` in `app.json` (iOS + Android)

### You need to sync to the primary checkout
```bash
cd "/Users/blackbird/.cursor/worktrees/rn-sane-charts/esf"
pnpm sync:primary
```

### Then in the primary checkout
```bash
cd "/Users/blackbird/Dropbox/MBP_Projects/dataviz/rn-sane-charts"
pnpm install --no-frozen-lockfile
DEVICE_UDID="5D137119-D4FA-4304-93CF-7162895D3123" pnpm ios:start

This will:
- Use SDK 54 + legacy bridge
- Rebuild cleanly
- Remove the bridgeless TurboModule failure

That error means **Skia is being registered twice**. It almost always happens when **two copies of `@shopify/react-native-skia`** are being linked into the same app (or two example apps are being bundled).

### Most likely causes
1) **Two Skia versions in the workspace**
2) **Both example apps are being bundled** (`packages/examples` and `packages/rn/example`)
3) **Metro resolving duplicate packages** across workspace roots

### Fix (do this in primary checkout)
```bash
cd "/Users/blackbird/Dropbox/MBP_Projects/dataviz/rn-sane-charts"

# Check if multiple Skia copies are installed
pnpm why @shopify/react-native-skia

# Clean and reinstall to ensure single version
rm -rf node_modules pnpm-lock.yaml
pnpm install --no-frozen-lockfile
```

Then ensure you are launching **only** `packages/examples`:

```bash
pnpm --dir packages/examples ios:rebuild
```

### If it still happens
Make sure Metro only targets the examples app:

```bash
pnpm --dir packages/examples start --clear
```

And confirm `packages/rn/example` is not running or bundled.

This error usually means Metro isn‚Äôt resolving the workspace `node_modules` in a pnpm monorepo. I updated the **worktree** `packages/ExamplesBare/metro.config.js` to explicitly resolve both the package and workspace roots.

You need the same change in the **Dropbox** checkout. Here‚Äôs the exact config to use:

```
const path = require('path');
const { getDefaultConfig, mergeConfig } = require('@react-native/metro-config');

/**
 * Metro configuration
 * https://reactnative.dev/docs/metro
 *
 * @type {import('@react-native/metro-config').MetroConfig}
 */
const projectRoot = __dirname;
const workspaceRoot = path.resolve(projectRoot, '../..');

const config = {
  // Ensure Metro resolves deps from both package and workspace roots.
  watchFolders: [workspaceRoot],
  resolver: {
    nodeModulesPaths: [
      path.join(projectRoot, 'node_modules'),
      path.join(workspaceRoot, 'node_modules'),
    ],
  },
};

module.exports = mergeConfig(getDefaultConfig(projectRoot), config);
```

After applying it, restart Metro:

```
cd /Users/blackbird/Dropbox/MBP_Projects/dataviz/rn-sane-charts/packages/ExamplesBare

Short answer: **Git does not sync automatically.** A commit is always local until you explicitly `git push`. And `origin/main` can also move forward when someone else (or you from another machine/worktree) pushes.

In your case:
- You had **local commits on `main`** that weren‚Äôt pushed.
- Separately, `origin/main` had **new commits** (likely from a previous push or another source).
- That‚Äôs why they diverged.

A commit only ‚Äúsyncs‚Äù when you:
- `git push` to publish local commits, and
- `git pull` (or `git fetch` + `git rebase/merge`) to bring remote commits into your local branch.

If you want, I can give you a simple 3‚Äëcommand routine to keep things aligned going forward.
